p.s: Boris Johnson tries to convince the audience to take action against the climate change and to help our friends.
In the beginning of the speech the author compares a bomb with the climate change to illustrate the audience the issue (l. 1-9).
With sentences like We know what the scientists tell us, ... (l. 9) the author uses inclusive language to get the audience into his point of view.
He also compares the audience and all other people with James Bond (l. 6).
We are in the same position as James Bond in his films but we have to find the right wire in real life to defuse or climate bomb.
The next paragraph informs about the useless plans of the meetings in Copenhagen 2010 and in Paris 2015.
For Boris Johnson the plans were just blah, blah, blah (l. 13).
In the following sentences the author says that we can deactivate that ticking doomsday device because we have the right technology (l. 16).
Furthermore he uses the inclusive words we can (l. 16) two times in the same line.
With the repetition of these words the audience feelfeels confident to go against climate change.
In one of the next paragraphs Boris Johnson says that they have the opportunity to spend a lot of money to work together and to end the dependence on coal which is a bad fossil fuel (l. 22-29).
As well as in the other paragraph Johnson uses inclusive language.

body.p: He also repeats the technology which is important to go against climate change (l. 30).We have the technology.We can find the finance, ...(l. 30). With this anaphora combined with the inclusive language Boris Johnson givegives the audience a way to think about climate change and some possible improvements.

p.s: In addition Boris Johnson is of the average age of the world leaders in Glasgow (l. 35).
He says the children who will judge us our children not yet born (l. 38).
With these words the audience can identify the issue as an issue for the next generations and for the future.
Johnson also talks about his fear of a possible fail of the plans against climate change because the next generations will not forgive (l. 40).
In the end of the speech Johnson repeats the bomb example and the importance of a begin of a fight against climate change.
Boris Johnson uses a lot of inclusive language to create a community spirit.
He also uses a metaphor two times in his speech.
A doomsday device (l. 3) which should illustrate his example fluff out lines or muss our cue (l. 40) is the other metaphor which should give the audience an example to make his words more visible.
All in all one can say that Boris Johnson's way of the try to convince the reader to take action against climate change is successful.
The fight against climate change is getting bigger every day in the entire world.
